## Offensive

The "Deterrence of Aggression" operation, initiated on November 27, 2024, by Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and allied rebel groups, represents a pivotal moment in the ongoing Syrian conflict. This offensive has been marked by rapid territorial gains, with reports confirming the capture of over 50 strategic towns and villages in northwestern Syria, highlighting the coordination and military capabilities of the opposition forces <citation>https://ca-syr.org/report/opposition-launches-offensive-northwest-syria</citation>. Notably, HTS succeeded in seizing the 46th Regiment base near Aleppo, which significantly undermined the Assad regime's control in the region <citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/hts-led-offensive-captures-46th-regiment-base-near-aleppo-c0f307bb</citation>.

The offensive has also led to intense clashes, with casualty reports indicating at least 57 individuals killed, including Syrian soldiers and fighters from HTS and allied factions <citation>https://english.aawsat.com/arab-world/5086203-‘deterring-aggression’-operation-escalates-northern-syria-frontline</citation>. The fierce fighting reflects the high stakes involved and the unwillingness of the Syrian government, supported by Russian airstrikes, to relinquish control over these critical territories <citation>https://www.counterextremism.com/blog/counterpoint-brief-rebels-seize-aleppo-renewing-fighting-decade-long-syrian-conflict</citation>.

Overall, the "Deterrence of Aggression" operation marks a significant strategic shift in the Syrian conflict, potentially altering established power dynamics and prompting discussions on the impact of these developments on regional stability <citation>https://lansinginstitute.org/2024/12/02/hts-offensive-and-its-global-implications/</citation>.

### Ukraine's Military Support for the Syrian Opposition

In recent developments, Ukraine has actively supported Syrian opposition forces as part of its broader strategy to diminish Russian influence in the Middle East. Reports indicate that Ukrainian intelligence operatives provided substantial military assistance, including approximately 150 drones and around 20 drone operators, to Syrian rebels ahead of a significant offensive in late November 2024, which led to the ousting of President Bashar al-Assad's government after 24 years in power <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/ukrainian-operatives-aided-syrian-rebels-with-drones-washington-post-reports-2024-12-11/</citation>.

This military collaboration primarily aimed to counteract the Russian regime’s longstanding ally, Assad, and to exploit the vulnerabilities in the Syrian government's defenses amidst ongoing shifts in military dynamics due to the war in Ukraine. The support was not only material but also tactical, with Ukrainian operatives reportedly engaging in planning and coordinating operations with Syrian rebel groups, significantly enhancing their capabilities on the battlefield <citation>https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2024/12/10/ukraine-syria-russia-war/</citation>.

The Lightning Offensive, initiated on November 27, 2024, underscores the effectiveness of this support as rebel forces, led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), managed to seize control of key territories, including major cities such as Aleppo, through advanced military tactics and drone-assisted assaults <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. By leveraging operational intelligence and strategic military training facilitated by Ukraine, the Syrian rebels achieved unprecedented gains, marking a dramatic shift in the balance of power within Syria and potentially altering the regional geopolitical landscape.

This development not only reflects a pivotal moment for Syrian opposition forces but also highlights the complexities of international responses to the Syrian Civil War. Ukraine's involvement exemplifies how conflicts can intertwine, prompting countries to reassess their military and diplomatic strategies in response to evolving alliances and threats <citation>https://cpa.org.au/guardian/issue-2129/the-ukrainian-connection-with-islamist-hts-militants-in-syria/</citation>.

### Clashes between SDF and opposition forces

The recent escalation of hostilities between the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) and opposition groups has sharply intensified since late November 2024. The Lightning Offensive, initiated by rebel factions led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), resulted in the capture of strategic areas and cities, including Aleppo, marking a significant shift in the Syrian civil war dynamics. This operation, characterized by military precision and coordination among various opposing groups, enabled rebels to seize over 15 villages within days, showcasing their enhanced military capabilities.<citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>

Simultaneously, reports indicate that the SDF is actively coordinating with international partners, including the United States and Russia, to manage the rapidly evolving security landscape. These efforts are particularly focused on safeguarding civilians amid intense fighting, with significant numbers of internally displaced persons (IDPs) seeking refuge in SDF-controlled areas following rebel advances.<citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/sdf-leader-mazlum-abdi-coordinates-safe-evacuations-tal-rifaat-shahba-amid-seven-8927a7c3</citation> 

The humanitarian crisis resulting from clashes has led to dire conditions for the displaced populations. As of early December 2024, approximately 85,000 IDPs fled from the Shahba and Tal Rifaat regions due to the aggression from Turkey-backed SNA forces, escalating the need for coordinated humanitarian responses in the region. The SDF’s initiatives to evacuate residents from these conflict zones reflect the urgency required to address the humanitarian fallout from ongoing military operations.<citation>https://www.kurdishpeace.org/policy/northern-syria-crisis-update-december-6-2024/</citation> 

In conclusion, the clashes between the SDF and opposition forces encapsulate a multifaceted conflict marked by territorial battles, significant military mobilization, and an urgent humanitarian response necessitated by the displacement crisis. This evolving landscape underscores the complex interplay of military strategy and humanitarian considerations in the region, with implications for future stability.

### Domestic

The recent Lightning Offensive has unleashed profound changes within Syria's domestic landscape, leading to the dramatic fall of President Bashar al-Assad's regime after over five decades of rule. As rebel forces launched their offensive on November 27, 2024, they swiftly gained momentum, capturing strategic cities such as Aleppo and Homs before ultimately encircling and entering Damascus on December 8, 2024. This rapid succession of events has not only resulted in significant territorial losses for the Assad regime but has also ignited celebrations among civilians, marking a pivotal turn in the Syrian civil war and reshaping the very fabric of Syrian society.

The rebellion, predominantly led by Islamist factions such as Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), caught Syrian government forces off guard, culminating in their unparalleled territorial gains across northern Syria. Approximately 50 strategic towns and villages were seized, signaling the severe operational shortcomings of the Syrian Arab Army (SAA) and highlighting a stark transformation in the balance of power within the country. Reports indicate that this offensive has resulted in thousands of casualties, including approximately 3,100 rebel fighters and over 15,500 government personnel killed, alongside significant civilian casualties estimated to be around 12,300.<citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>

In the wake of this turmoil, the international and regional responses have also been notable. Iran has reiterated its support for Assad, with Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi pledging unwavering backing during critical meetings in Damascus shortly before the offensive escalated.<citation>https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/middle-east-latest-syrias-government-appears-to-fall-after-lightning-offensive-by-insurgents/VRV6SVJV2BE3BIEPJRIOQD5NSM/</citation> However, the speed and decisiveness of the rebel advance have raised questions about Iran’s diminishing influence in the region, as the power dynamics shift rapidly against the backdrop of these recent developments.<citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation> 

The collapse of the Assad regime not only heralds a new era in Syrian politics but also prompts urgent discussions regarding the future governance structure. As the transitional phase unfolds, the nature of political collaboration and reconstruction in a post-Assad Syria will likely be critical issues, particularly given the prevailing sectarian tensions and regional rivalries that have fuelled the conflict for over a decade. The ensuing power vacuum may provoke further instability unless a broad-based leadership emerges that can command widespread support across Syria's diverse social fabric.<citation>https://www.9news.com.au/world/syrian-insurgents-say-they-have-entered-damascus-as-residents-of-capital-report-sounds-of-gunfire/5311e54a-c6e1-4c9d-a398-be687791743c</citation> As the situation continues to evolve, the implications of the Lightning Offensive will reverberate far beyond Syria, affecting regional geopolitics and international alignments.

### Opening advances

The Lightning Offensive, which commenced on November 27, 2024, significantly altered the dynamics of the Syrian conflict. Led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and allied forces, the offensive resulted in the rapid capture of over 200 locations, including strategic towns and cities like Aleppo, marking one of the most substantial advances for opposition forces in years <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/02/syrian-hts-led-forces-capture-over-200-locations-from-assad-forces-in-aleppo-idlib-and-hama/</citation>. This unprecedented operation not only showcased HTS's military efficiency and tactical advancements—such as the effective deployment of drone strikes—but also highlighted the vulnerabilities of the Syrian military, which has struggled to maintain coherence amidst ongoing external pressures, particularly from Russian involvement and regional shifts in support <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

As rebel forces executed a concerted strategy to encircle major cities, they garnered control over urban infrastructure critical for logistics and governance. The fall of Aleppo, an economic linchpin, and the subsequent push toward Damascus underscored a tangible shift in military control, effectively leaving the Assad regime's authority in disarray. Casualty figures reflected the intensity of these clashes, with reports indicating substantial losses on both sides, including the death of numerous civilians caught in the crossfire <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria</citation>.

This escalation has severe implications not only for the operational landscape but also for the humanitarian situation, prompting significant displacement and a crisis of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in regions like northeastern Syria <citation>https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/031220244</citation>. The complexities of governance in these areas are challenged as the Kurdish-led administration activates emergency measures to accommodate the influx of IDPs fleeing the violence <citation>https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/031220244</citation>. Thus, the advances by HTS through the Lightning Offensive have not only shifted territorial control but have also ignited a renewed wave of humanitarian needs and strategic recalibrations among various military and political actors in the region.

### Iran

Iran has been a pivotal ally of Bashar al-Assad's regime since the Syrian civil war erupted in 2011, providing substantial military support that has been crucial for the regime's survival. Throughout the conflict, Iran operated military bases and logistics hubs in Syria, facilitating arms transfers to various militant groups aligned with its interests. This involvement solidified Iran's rhetoric of the 'Axis of Resistance,' which includes Hezbollah and other allied groups, illustrating its strategic goals in countering U.S. and Israeli influences in the region.

However, following significant territorial losses to rebel forces in late 2024, particularly during the 'Lightning Offensive' which saw the capture of key cities like Aleppo, the Assad regime's position has become increasingly precarious. Reports indicate that Iran began evacuating military commanders and personnel from Syria as rebel forces gained traction and captured significant areas, marking a notable withdrawal of Iranian influence <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/06/world/middleeast/iran-syria-evacuation.html</citation>.

These developments have profound implications for Iran's role in the region. The fall of major Assad strongholds signifies not just a military setback but a potential shift in the balance of power, raising questions about Iran's ability to project its influence through its Syrian ally. The Iranian regime's ongoing support for Assad has been characterized by a heavy investment of resources, estimated to be between $30 to $50 billion, but the changing tides may compel a reevaluation of military and strategic commitments <citation>https://carnegieendowment.org/middle-east/diwan/2024/12/why-did-iran-allow-assads-downfall?lang=en</citation>.

Despite Iran's longstanding partnership with Syria, the evolving situation post-Assad suggests a need for Iran to adapt its strategy as new governance structures emerge. Should the conflict give way to internal divisions within Syria, Iran might attempt to leverage its existing alliances to assert influence under different circumstances, thereby negotiating a role for itself in a potentially fractured political landscape <citation>https://worldpolicyhub.com/iran-and-syria-after-assad-caution-and-anticipation/</citation>.

Overall, while Iran has historically sought to maintain a foothold in Syria, the recent offensive underscores a significant shift that could further complicate its strategic calculations and diminish its say in regional matters.

### Closing offensives

The "Lightning Offensive," launched on November 27, 2024, marked a pivotal moment in the Syrian civil war as rebel forces, particularly led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), executed a coordinated assault that resulted in the rapid capture of Aleppo, significantly altering the dynamics of the conflict. Within days, rebel factions seized approximately 200 locations across Aleppo, Idlib, and Hama, leading to territorial gains that had not been achieved in years <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/02/syrian-hts-led-forces-capture-over-200-locations-from-assad-forces-in-aleppo-idlib-and-hama/</citation>.

The operation leveraged advanced military tactics, including the use of drone strikes to neutralize Syrian artillery positions, showcasing a remarkable evolution in the capabilities of the opposition forces <citation>https://themedialine.org/top-stories/rebels-advance-on-aleppo-with-new-weapons-analysts-say-turkey-gains-as-iran-falters/</citation>. This rapid and effective offensive highlighted significant vulnerabilities within the Syrian government forces, who were largely caught off guard and suffered substantial territorial losses, including key military assets like Base 46 <citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/hts-led-offensive-captures-46th-regiment-base-near-aleppo-c0f307bb</citation>.

In the wake of these developments, the Assad regime's capacity to maintain control over strategically vital areas has come under severe strain, leading to intense airstrikes by Russian and Syrian forces aimed at reclaiming lost territories <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/syrian-militants-seize-control-of-most-of-aleppo/a-70926443</citation>. Moreover, the regional implications are substantial; the shifting balance of power could alter alliances and influence in Syria, particularly as discussions around the role of Iranian support for the Assad regime are being reevaluated, reflecting potential declines in Iranian military and political footholds amidst HTS's resurgence <citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation>.

The impacts of this offensive extend beyond immediate military engagements; humanitarian crises are exacerbating as the influx of internally displaced persons from conflict zones has surged, calling into question the capacity of local authorities to manage these emergencies and highlighting the dire need for international assistance <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/displaced-syrian-kurds-face-dire-conditions-amid-intensified-fighting-/7888678.html</citation>.

Overall, the recent developments in Aleppo not only signify a crucial turning point in the Syrian conflict but also underscore the complex interplay between military advances, regional geopolitics, and humanitarian challenges that need to be addressed as the situation continues to unfold.

### Immediate aftermath

In the wake of significant military offensives in December 2024, notably dubbed the Lightning Offensive, rebel forces have successfully captured strategically vital territories, including Aleppo and its surrounding regions. This marked a dramatic shift in the power dynamics of the Syrian Civil War, showcasing a notable decline in the Assad regime's control and military effectiveness. Within mere days, opposition groups, predominantly led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), executed a series of coordinated attacks, leading to the capture of numerous towns and laying siege to critical government positions <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

## Impact of the "Deterrence of Aggression" Operation

The "Deterrence of Aggression" operation has indelibly affected the military and political landscape of Syria. Launched on November 27, 2024, this offensive, spearheaded by Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and various allied factions, has led to significant territorial gains, including the strategic capture of the city of Aleppo, a pivotal stronghold for the Assad regime. Within just a few days, rebel forces achieved control over a vast number of towns and villages, marking the most substantial territorial expansion in years and fundamentally shifting the balance of power in the conflict <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

The operational success of the HTS-led coalition can be attributed to advanced military tactics, including coordinated drone strikes and ground assaults, which showcased a remarkable evolution in the capabilities of opposition forces <citation>https://thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. However, this offensive was not without cost; reports suggest that over 15,500 government forces and approximately 3,100 rebel fighters lost their lives during this intense conflict, underlining the operation's high-stakes environment <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

As the HTS and its allies successfully encircled key regime positions and pushed towards Damascus, concerns arose regarding the declining influence of external powers such as Iran and Russia, which had previously supported the Assad regime <citation>https://cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation>. The international response to the operation also reflects a recalibration of geopolitical strategies, as Turkey has assumed a more active role, aiming to stabilize the region while containing Kurdish dynamics amid the rapidly changing circumstances <citation>https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/new-war-syria-turkey-syrian-national-army-vs-us-syrian-democratic-forces-13844132.html</citation>.

### Fall of Damascus

The 'Fall of Damascus' represents a pivotal moment in the Syrian civil war, culminating from a decisive military offensive launched by opposition forces in late 2024. This campaign, initiated on November 27 under the banner of "Deterrence of Aggression," saw various rebel factions, prominently Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), execute a well-coordinated and rapid assault that ultimately dismantled the Assad regime's long-standing control over Syria.

**Phase 1: The Northern Blitz (November 27 - December 1, 2024)**  
The initial phase of the offensive began with a surprise attack on Aleppo—Syria's largest city. On November 27, 2024, HTS and allied factions infiltrated government defenses, quickly capturing strategic locations and overwhelming Syrian forces. Within just a few days, much of Aleppo fell into rebel hands, marking a critical turning point in the conflict. Reports indicate that over 3,000 Syrian soldiers were killed or captured during this phase, while rebel forces lost approximately 600 fighters <citation>https://www.defensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

**Phase 2: The Central Offensive (December 2 - December 5, 2024)**  
The offensive shifted gears as the Turkish-backed Syrian National Army (SNA) launched coordinated assaults on Hama and Homs. Armed with advanced weaponry and support, they swiftly overwhelmed government checkpoints. By December 5, both Hama and Homs were under rebel control, effectively isolating Damascus from northern Syria and severely crippling the Assad regime’s military capabilities. This phase resulted in significant casualties, with rebel forces suffering about 800 fatalities <citation>https://thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

**Phase 3: The Southern Push (December 6 - December 9, 2024)**  
With control over Hama and Homs, the opposition launched targeted offensives in southern Syria, capturing critical locations like Daraa, which had historical significance as the birthplace of the 2011 uprising. By December 9, the rebels had fully consolidated their gains in the south, effectively cutting off the Assad regime from its key resources in the region. This phase was characterized by intense urban warfare, leading to over 2,000 government casualties <citation>https://thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

**Phase 4: The Siege of Damascus (December 10 - December 14, 2024)**  
The culmination of the offensive occurred as rebel forces encircled Damascus. This siege marked the final stand for Assad's forces, who were heavily outnumbered and demoralized from the rapid losses suffered in previous phases. By December 14, 2024, considerable military pressure led to the capture of the capital and the collapse of the Assad regime's control, signifying over 6,000 government casualties and creating a humanitarian crisis with significant civilian displacement <citation>https://www.defensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. 

Overall, the 'Fall of Damascus' has transformed the landscape of Syrian politics, posing questions about the future governance of a nation wishing to rebuild after years of civil strife.

### Israel

Since the significant shift in the Syrian political landscape following the fall of Bashar al-Assad's regime in December 2024, Israel has dramatically escalated its military operations in Syria. The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have launched an extensive series of airstrikes targeted at military positions associated with Hezbollah and Iranian forces. Reports indicate that these operations intensified notably between December 8 and December 10, with approximately 480 Israeli airstrikes documented during this period alone, representing one of the largest military escalations in recent years <citation>https://www.harmoon.org/en/researches/israeli/</citation>.

Israeli military officials have articulated that these airstrikes aim to dismantle the military capabilities of the Assad regime, which they perceive as a direct threat due to its historic alliance with Iran and Hezbollah. Netanyahu has publicly claimed that Israel's military actions were pivotal in contributing to the regime's collapse, stating, "The Assad regime fell because of Israeli strikes on Iran and Hezbollah" <citation>https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/world/3253571/netanyahu-assad-regime-fell-because-israeli-strikes-iran-hezbollah/</citation>. This assertion underscores Israel’s narrative of preemptive self-defense amidst a shifting geopolitical landscape.

Moreover, Israel's military strategy in Syria has not solely been reactive; rather, it appears to be deeply entrenched in the expansion of Israeli territorial control. Following the regime's downfall, Israeli forces have occupied substantial areas previously held by the Assad regime, crossing into the demilitarized zones stipulated by the 1974 disengagement agreement. Current estimates suggest that Israeli control has expanded to cover approximately 460 square kilometers within Syrian territory <citation>https://www.dohainstitute.org/en/PoliticalStudies/Pages/israeli-policy-on-syria-after-fall-of-assad-regime.aspx</citation>. This occupation is aimed at creating a buffer zone to counter potential threats from Iranian-aligned militias and to reinforce Israel’s security framework in the region.

The implications of Israel's continued military operations and territorial advancements are significant. These actions could exacerbate tensions with not only Syrian authorities but also with Iran, which has vowed to respond to Israeli aggression by establishing new resistance groups in Syria <citation>https://english.alarabiya.net/News/middle-east/2024/12/31/iran-security-chief-says-new-resistance-against-israel-to-emerge-in-syria</citation>. As the situation evolves, the potential for renewed hostilities within the already fragmented Syrian landscape remains a concern, signaling a new chapter in both Israel’s military strategy and the broader regional dynamics.

### International

The fall of Bashar al-Assad's regime on December 8, 2024, stirred a variety of international reactions, reflecting the complex geopolitical landscape of the Middle East. Following the regime's collapse, Yemen celebrated the event as a "historic moment," showcasing a sense of relief among nations hostile to Assad's authoritarian rule <citation>https://www.thehill.com/homenews/ap/ap-international/ap-global-reaction-to-assads-sudden-ouster-from-syria-ranges-from-jubilation-to-alarm/</citation>. Conversely, Israel viewed the development as favorable, emphasizing the eradication of Iranian military presence in Syria, which had consistently posed a security threat to its borders <citation>https://www.firstpost.com/world/heres-how-west-asian-nations-international-community-reacted-to-fall-assad-regime-in-syria-13842784.html</citation>.

Turkey, a significant player in the Syrian conflict due to its long-standing opposition to Assad, sees this as a crucial opportunity to reshuffle the governance landscape in Syria and curb any Kurdish ambitions in the region. Turkish officials underscored their commitment to boxing in Kurdish forces while pledging to assist in stabilizing the newly formed government <citation>https://www.chathamhouse.org/2024/12/turkey-has-emerged-winner-syria-must-now-use-its-influence-help-build-peace</citation>. In essence, Turkey positions itself as a pivotal actor in post-Assad Syria, with interests aimed at securing a buffer along its border.

The European Union responded promptly, pledging €2.12 billion in aid aimed at recovery and rebuilding efforts in Syria, reflecting a commitment to humanitarian support and stability in the region <citation>https://enlargement.ec.europa.eu/news/eu-pledges-eu212-billion-support-future-syria-and-region-during-brussels-eight-conference-2024-05-28_en</citation>. The EU's statement emphasized the need for a peaceful and inclusive transition reflecting the aspirations of the Syrian people.

Iran's reaction was notably cautious, as it articulated respect for Syrian sovereignty while recognizing that the future of Syria should be determined by its citizens without external interference <citation>https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2024/12/08/3215704/iran-emphasizes-syrian-people-s-role-in-deciding-country-s-future</citation>. This indicates a shift in Iran's approach as it recalibrates its influence amidst the newfound instability.

Furthermore, Ukraine seized the opportunity to express its support for the new Syrian government, aligning its interests with the opposition to undermine Russian influence in the region <citation>https://www.newsweek.com/top-ukraine-official-pledges-support-new-syrian-government-2007602</citation>. The international community's diverse reactions underline the multifaceted implications of the Assad regime's fall, suggesting that the future of Syria will not only be shaped by its internal dynamics but also profoundly influenced by global geopolitics.

## Analysis

The Lightning Offensive launched by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) on November 27, 2024, signifies a pivotal shift in the Syrian civil war, capturing the strategic city of Aleppo within days and marking a notable resurgence of opposition forces. This operation, characterized by high levels of military precision and coordination among various factions, resulted in the occupation of over 200 strategic locations across Aleppo, Idlib, and Hama, reflecting the largest territorial gains for the opposition in recent years <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/02/syrian-hts-led-forces-capture-over-200-locations-from-assad-forces-in-aleppo-idlib-and-hama/</citation>.

The success of the offensive reveals significant vulnerabilities in the Syrian military's capabilities, largely attributed to logistical issues and low troop morale that have exacerbated over years of continuous conflict. HTS and allied forces utilized advanced military tactics, including coordinated ground assaults and drone strikes, to neutralize government artillery positions, showcasing a substantial evolution in their combat effectiveness <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. The offensive resulted in significant casualties: approximately 3,100 rebels and over 15,500 government fighters lost their lives during this aggressive campaign <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>, and over 178,000 individuals were displaced due to the heightened violence <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>.

The rapid territorial gains by opposition forces indicate a significant evolution in their military capabilities, employing modern tactics including drone strikes and coordinated assaults <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. Furthermore, discussions surrounding the humanitarian crisis are increasingly pressing, with approximately 178,000 individuals displaced as a direct result of the escalated conflict in northern Syria <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>.

The political implications extend beyond Syrian borders, as the offensive may redefine the balance of power among various regional actors, notably diminishing Iranian influence and altering Turkey’s strategic posture amidst rising tensions with Kurdish factions <citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation>. As HTS positions itself as a pragmatic governance force, moving away from its al-Qaeda roots, the complexities of post-Assad Syria will undoubtedly demand careful consideration of various factions’ roles and their impacts on regional stability <citation>https://www.geo-ref.net/en/sy-hts.htm</citation>. In summary, these developments herald a potentially transformative phase in the Syrian conflict, bringing both opportunities and challenges as the international community and regional powers recalibrate their strategies in response to these rapid changes.

### Capture of Hama

On December 6, 2024, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) successfully captured Hama city following a swift and coordinated military offensive that commenced shortly after the fall of Aleppo. This marked a significant territorial gain for HTS and allied rebels during the ongoing conflict, showcasing their ability to capitalize on government vulnerabilities. Reports indicate that the offensive in Hama was characterized by intense clashes with pro-government forces who were unable to maintain their positions effectively as HTS advanced, leading to the ousting of government troops from the city <citation>https://syrianobserver.com/syrian-actors/hts-takes-control-of-hama-following-government-withdrawal.html</citation>.

Prior to the capture, government forces attempted to mount counterattacks to repel the advancing rebels. These countermeasures included sending reinforcements to fortify their positions near Hama and implementing aerial bombardments aimed at destroying the opposition’s supply lines. However, these efforts were largely ineffective; artillery strikes and airstrikes conducted by Syrian and Russian forces did not suffice to halt the momentum gained by HTS and its allies <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/syrian-army-sends-reinforcements-to-hold-back-rebels-in-hama/a-70930913</citation>.

The humanitarian crisis exacerbated by the conflict has drawn significant attention, with civilian casualties reported amidst the fighting. As of early December, more than 149 civilian deaths were recorded, including many women and children due to airstrikes and ground clashes. The UN and other humanitarian organizations have raised alarms about the escalating violence leading to the displacement of approximately 178,000 individuals fleeing conflict zones. These civilians face dire conditions, lacking access to essential services such as food, healthcare, and safe shelter <citation>https://snhr.org/blog/2024/12/04/149-civilians-killed-including-35-children-and-16-women-in-northern-syria-since-november-27-2024-up-until-december-3-2024/</citation> <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>.

Consequently, the dynamics in Hama not only reflect the immediate military engagements between HTS and government forces but also underscore the ongoing humanitarian crisis that arises from intensified conflict. The situation emphasizes the intricate relationship between military control and the humanitarian fallout impacting the civilian population caught amid these hostilities.

### Russia

In December 2023, the conflict in Syria witnessed an escalation as Syrian and Russian jets significantly intensified their airstrikes against opposition forces in northern regions, primarily focused around Aleppo. This military surge was initiated in response to rebel groups capturing essential territories, marking one of the most substantial military escalations since the ceasefire brokered in 2020. The operations aimed to counteract the recent successes of insurgent forces, including the surprise offensive led by aligned factions, which has dramatically recalibrated the territorial control dynamics in Syria. Reports indicated that these airstrikes were part of a broader strategy to reclaim lost ground and demonstrate Russia's ongoing commitment to support the Assad regime amidst challenges posed by cyclical rebel advancements <citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/01/middleeast/syrian-regime-airstrikes-opposition-forces-intl</citation>.

During this period, Syrian military officials claimed that over 400 insurgents were killed in a coordinated series of joint airstrikes within a short timeframe. This aggressive response reflects Russia's strategic focus on absorbing and mitigating the impacts of rebel successes, as these developments pose heightened risks to its influence and military objectives in the region <citation>https://news.sky.com/story/syria-says-its-strikes-with-russia-have-killed-at-least-400-insurgents-over-past-24-hours-13265595</citation>. The rapid territorial gains made by opposition forces signify a pivotal shift and reveal the complexities of the conflict, wherein Russian military operations must adapt to the changing landscape shaped by rebel aspirations and external alliances <citation>https://carnegieendowment.org/russia-eurasia/politika/2024/12/russia-syria-uprising-problems?lang=en</citation>.

As Syria continues to grapple with internal discord and external military pressures, the developments of late 2023 emphasize the intricate webs of alliances and confrontations that not only determine the course of the Syrian conflict but also impact Russia’s strategic goals within the Middle East.
## Offensive

The "Deterrence of Aggression" operation, initiated on November 27, 2024, by Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and allied rebel groups, represents a pivotal moment in the ongoing Syrian conflict. This offensive has been marked by rapid territorial gains, with reports confirming the capture of over 50 strategic towns and villages in northwestern Syria, highlighting the coordination and military capabilities of the opposition forces <citation>https://ca-syr.org/report/opposition-launches-offensive-northwest-syria</citation>. Notably, HTS succeeded in seizing the 46th Regiment base near Aleppo, which significantly undermined the Assad regime's control in the region <citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/hts-led-offensive-captures-46th-regiment-base-near-aleppo-c0f307bb</citation>.

The offensive has also led to intense clashes, with casualty reports indicating at least 57 individuals killed, including Syrian soldiers and fighters from HTS and allied factions <citation>https://english.aawsat.com/arab-world/5086203-‘deterring-aggression’-operation-escalates-northern-syria-frontline</citation>. The fierce fighting reflects the high stakes involved and the unwillingness of the Syrian government, supported by Russian airstrikes, to relinquish control over these critical territories <citation>https://www.counterextremism.com/blog/counterpoint-brief-rebels-seize-aleppo-renewing-fighting-decade-long-syrian-conflict</citation>.

Overall, the "Deterrence of Aggression" operation marks a significant strategic shift in the Syrian conflict, potentially altering established power dynamics and prompting discussions on the impact of these developments on regional stability <citation>https://lansinginstitute.org/2024/12/02/hts-offensive-and-its-global-implications/</citation>.
### Ukraine's Military Support for the Syrian Opposition

In recent developments, Ukraine has actively supported Syrian opposition forces as part of its broader strategy to diminish Russian influence in the Middle East. Reports indicate that Ukrainian intelligence operatives provided substantial military assistance, including approximately 150 drones and around 20 drone operators, to Syrian rebels ahead of a significant offensive in late November 2024, which led to the ousting of President Bashar al-Assad's government after 24 years in power <citation>https://www.reuters.com/world/ukrainian-operatives-aided-syrian-rebels-with-drones-washington-post-reports-2024-12-11/</citation>.

This military collaboration primarily aimed to counteract the Russian regime’s longstanding ally, Assad, and to exploit the vulnerabilities in the Syrian government's defenses amidst ongoing shifts in military dynamics due to the war in Ukraine. The support was not only material but also tactical, with Ukrainian operatives reportedly engaging in planning and coordinating operations with Syrian rebel groups, significantly enhancing their capabilities on the battlefield <citation>https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2024/12/10/ukraine-syria-russia-war/</citation>.

The Lightning Offensive, initiated on November 27, 2024, underscores the effectiveness of this support as rebel forces, led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), managed to seize control of key territories, including major cities such as Aleppo, through advanced military tactics and drone-assisted assaults <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>. By leveraging operational intelligence and strategic military training facilitated by Ukraine, the Syrian rebels achieved unprecedented gains, marking a dramatic shift in the balance of power within Syria and potentially altering the regional geopolitical landscape.

This development not only reflects a pivotal moment for Syrian opposition forces but also highlights the complexities of international responses to the Syrian Civil War. Ukraine's involvement exemplifies how conflicts can intertwine, prompting countries to reassess their military and diplomatic strategies in response to evolving alliances and threats <citation>https://cpa.org.au/guardian/issue-2129/the-ukrainian-connection-with-islamist-hts-militants-in-syria/</citation>.
### Clashes between SDF and opposition forces

The recent escalation of hostilities between the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) and opposition groups has sharply intensified since late November 2024. The Lightning Offensive, initiated by rebel factions led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), resulted in the capture of strategic areas and cities, including Aleppo, marking a significant shift in the Syrian civil war dynamics. This operation, characterized by military precision and coordination among various opposing groups, enabled rebels to seize over 15 villages within days, showcasing their enhanced military capabilities.<citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>

Simultaneously, reports indicate that the SDF is actively coordinating with international partners, including the United States and Russia, to manage the rapidly evolving security landscape. These efforts are particularly focused on safeguarding civilians amid intense fighting, with significant numbers of internally displaced persons (IDPs) seeking refuge in SDF-controlled areas following rebel advances.<citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/sdf-leader-mazlum-abdi-coordinates-safe-evacuations-tal-rifaat-shahba-amid-seven-8927a7c3</citation> 

The humanitarian crisis resulting from clashes has led to dire conditions for the displaced populations. As of early December 2024, approximately 85,000 IDPs fled from the Shahba and Tal Rifaat regions due to the aggression from Turkey-backed SNA forces, escalating the need for coordinated humanitarian responses in the region. The SDF’s initiatives to evacuate residents from these conflict zones reflect the urgency required to address the humanitarian fallout from ongoing military operations.<citation>https://www.kurdishpeace.org/policy/northern-syria-crisis-update-december-6-2024/</citation> 

In conclusion, the clashes between the SDF and opposition forces encapsulate a multifaceted conflict marked by territorial battles, significant military mobilization, and an urgent humanitarian response necessitated by the displacement crisis. This evolving landscape underscores the complex interplay of military strategy and humanitarian considerations in the region, with implications for future stability.
### Domestic

The recent Lightning Offensive has unleashed profound changes within Syria's domestic landscape, leading to the dramatic fall of President Bashar al-Assad's regime after over five decades of rule. As rebel forces launched their offensive on November 27, 2024, they swiftly gained momentum, capturing strategic cities such as Aleppo and Homs before ultimately encircling and entering Damascus on December 8, 2024. This rapid succession of events has not only resulted in significant territorial losses for the Assad regime but has also ignited celebrations among civilians, marking a pivotal turn in the Syrian civil war and reshaping the very fabric of Syrian society.

The rebellion, predominantly led by Islamist factions such as Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), caught Syrian government forces off guard, culminating in their unparalleled territorial gains across northern Syria. Approximately 50 strategic towns and villages were seized, signaling the severe operational shortcomings of the Syrian Arab Army (SAA) and highlighting a stark transformation in the balance of power within the country. Reports indicate that this offensive has resulted in thousands of casualties, including approximately 3,100 rebel fighters and over 15,500 government personnel killed, alongside significant civilian casualties estimated to be around 12,300.<citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>

In the wake of this turmoil, the international and regional responses have also been notable. Iran has reiterated its support for Assad, with Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi pledging unwavering backing during critical meetings in Damascus shortly before the offensive escalated.<citation>https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/middle-east-latest-syrias-government-appears-to-fall-after-lightning-offensive-by-insurgents/VRV6SVJV2BE3BIEPJRIOQD5NSM/</citation> However, the speed and decisiveness of the rebel advance have raised questions about Iran’s diminishing influence in the region, as the power dynamics shift rapidly against the backdrop of these recent developments.<citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation> 

The collapse of the Assad regime not only heralds a new era in Syrian politics but also prompts urgent discussions regarding the future governance structure. As the transitional phase unfolds, the nature of political collaboration and reconstruction in a post-Assad Syria will likely be critical issues, particularly given the prevailing sectarian tensions and regional rivalries that have fuelled the conflict for over a decade. The ensuing power vacuum may provoke further instability unless a broad-based leadership emerges that can command widespread support across Syria's diverse social fabric.<citation>https://www.9news.com.au/world/syrian-insurgents-say-they-have-entered-damascus-as-residents-of-capital-report-sounds-of-gunfire/5311e54a-c6e1-4c9d-a398-be687791743c</citation> As the situation continues to evolve, the implications of the Lightning Offensive will reverberate far beyond Syria, affecting regional geopolitics and international alignments.
### Opening advances

The Lightning Offensive, which commenced on November 27, 2024, significantly altered the dynamics of the Syrian conflict. Led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) and allied forces, the offensive resulted in the rapid capture of over 200 locations, including strategic towns and cities like Aleppo, marking one of the most substantial advances for opposition forces in years <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/02/syrian-hts-led-forces-capture-over-200-locations-from-assad-forces-in-aleppo-idlib-and-hama/</citation>. This unprecedented operation not only showcased HTS's military efficiency and tactical advancements—such as the effective deployment of drone strikes—but also highlighted the vulnerabilities of the Syrian military, which has struggled to maintain coherence amidst ongoing external pressures, particularly from Russian involvement and regional shifts in support <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

As rebel forces executed a concerted strategy to encircle major cities, they garnered control over urban infrastructure critical for logistics and governance. The fall of Aleppo, an economic linchpin, and the subsequent push toward Damascus underscored a tangible shift in military control, effectively leaving the Assad regime's authority in disarray. Casualty figures reflected the intensity of these clashes, with reports indicating substantial losses on both sides, including the death of numerous civilians caught in the crossfire <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria</citation>.

This escalation has severe implications not only for the operational landscape but also for the humanitarian situation, prompting significant displacement and a crisis of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in regions like northeastern Syria <citation>https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/031220244</citation>. The complexities of governance in these areas are challenged as the Kurdish-led administration activates emergency measures to accommodate the influx of IDPs fleeing the violence <citation>https://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/031220244</citation>. Thus, the advances by HTS through the Lightning Offensive have not only shifted territorial control but have also ignited a renewed wave of humanitarian needs and strategic recalibrations among various military and political actors in the region.
### Iran

Iran has been a pivotal ally of Bashar al-Assad's regime since the Syrian civil war erupted in 2011, providing substantial military support that has been crucial for the regime's survival. Throughout the conflict, Iran operated military bases and logistics hubs in Syria, facilitating arms transfers to various militant groups aligned with its interests. This involvement solidified Iran's rhetoric of the 'Axis of Resistance,' which includes Hezbollah and other allied groups, illustrating its strategic goals in countering U.S. and Israeli influences in the region.

However, following significant territorial losses to rebel forces in late 2024, particularly during the 'Lightning Offensive' which saw the capture of key cities like Aleppo, the Assad regime's position has become increasingly precarious. Reports indicate that Iran began evacuating military commanders and personnel from Syria as rebel forces gained traction and captured significant areas, marking a notable withdrawal of Iranian influence <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/06/world/middleeast/iran-syria-evacuation.html</citation>.

These developments have profound implications for Iran's role in the region. The fall of major Assad strongholds signifies not just a military setback but a potential shift in the balance of power, raising questions about Iran's ability to project its influence through its Syrian ally. The Iranian regime's ongoing support for Assad has been characterized by a heavy investment of resources, estimated to be between $30 to $50 billion, but the changing tides may compel a reevaluation of military and strategic commitments <citation>https://carnegieendowment.org/middle-east/diwan/2024/12/why-did-iran-allow-assads-downfall?lang=en</citation>.

Despite Iran's longstanding partnership with Syria, the evolving situation post-Assad suggests a need for Iran to adapt its strategy as new governance structures emerge. Should the conflict give way to internal divisions within Syria, Iran might attempt to leverage its existing alliances to assert influence under different circumstances, thereby negotiating a role for itself in a potentially fractured political landscape <citation>https://worldpolicyhub.com/iran-and-syria-after-assad-caution-and-anticipation/</citation>.

Overall, while Iran has historically sought to maintain a foothold in Syria, the recent offensive underscores a significant shift that could further complicate its strategic calculations and diminish its say in regional matters.
### Turkey

In December 2024, Turkey's involvement in Syria has taken on a renewed significance following the sudden collapse of Bashar al-Assad's regime, primarily facilitated by the Lightning Offensive led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS). Turkey has emerged as a crucial player in shaping the post-Assad landscape, seeking to assert its influence over the newly formed governance structures in rebel-held regions while simultaneously addressing its security concerns regarding Kurdish entities, particularly the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF).

Turkey's strategic response encompassed supporting the SNA in its operations against Kurdish fighters while also engaging diplomatically with regional powers, including Russia and Iran, to ensure a stable transition in Syria. Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan emphasized that the recent victories of Syrian rebels not only represent a success for the opposition but also bolster Turkey's own interests in the region. This includes efforts to manage the influx of refugees and mitigate the threat from Kurdish militias, reflecting Ankara's longstanding objective of maintaining a buffer against perceived security threats along its southern border <citation>https://www.foreignaffairs.com/turkey/how-turkey-won-syrian-civil-war</citation>.

Moreover, Turkey's military operations in Syria, framed within the context of regional security, underscore the complexities of its role as both a supporter of opposition factions and a mediator in ongoing conflicts. The swift territorial gains achieved by HTS have highlighted significant vulnerabilities within the Syrian military and demonstrated a shifting balance of power in the region. As Turkish-backed forces capitalize on these developments, the future governance of Syria remains precarious, necessitating a careful approach to accommodate the myriad interests of diverse factions within the newly liberated territories <citation>https://www.wusf.org/2024-12-18/turkey-looks-set-to-play-an-outsize-role-in-shaping-the-new-syria-after-assad</citation>.

In conclusion, Turkey is actively positioning itself to shape the post-Assad order through military and diplomatic channels. Its efforts not only highlight its aspirations in Syria but also point to a potential reconfiguration of regional alliances, with implications for security and governance structures in a country that has been torn by a protracted civil war.
### Closing offensives

The "Lightning Offensive," launched on November 27, 2024, marked a pivotal moment in the Syrian civil war as rebel forces, particularly led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), executed a coordinated assault that resulted in the rapid capture of Aleppo, significantly altering the dynamics of the conflict. Within days, rebel factions seized approximately 200 locations across Aleppo, Idlib, and Hama, leading to territorial gains that had not been achieved in years <citation>https://acleddata.com/2024/12/02/syrian-hts-led-forces-capture-over-200-locations-from-assad-forces-in-aleppo-idlib-and-hama/</citation>.

The operation leveraged advanced military tactics, including the use of drone strikes to neutralize Syrian artillery positions, showcasing a remarkable evolution in the capabilities of the opposition forces <citation>https://themedialine.org/top-stories/rebels-advance-on-aleppo-with-new-weapons-analysts-say-turkey-gains-as-iran-falters/</citation>. This rapid and effective offensive highlighted significant vulnerabilities within the Syrian government forces, who were largely caught off guard and suffered substantial territorial losses, including key military assets like Base 46 <citation>https://deepnewz.com/middle-east/hts-led-offensive-captures-46th-regiment-base-near-aleppo-c0f307bb</citation>.

In the wake of these developments, the Assad regime's capacity to maintain control over strategically vital areas has come under severe strain, leading to intense airstrikes by Russian and Syrian forces aimed at reclaiming lost territories <citation>https://www.dw.com/en/syrian-militants-seize-control-of-most-of-aleppo/a-70926443</citation>. Moreover, the regional implications are substantial; the shifting balance of power could alter alliances and influence in Syria, particularly as discussions around the role of Iranian support for the Assad regime are being reevaluated, reflecting potential declines in Iranian military and political footholds amidst HTS's resurgence <citation>https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/what-syrias-revived-civil-war-means-region</citation>.

The impacts of this offensive extend beyond immediate military engagements; humanitarian crises are exacerbating as the influx of internally displaced persons from conflict zones has surged, calling into question the capacity of local authorities to manage these emergencies and highlighting the dire need for international assistance <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/displaced-syrian-kurds-face-dire-conditions-amid-intensified-fighting-/7888678.html</citation>.

Overall, the recent developments in Aleppo not only signify a crucial turning point in the Syrian conflict but also underscore the complex interplay between military advances, regional geopolitics, and humanitarian challenges that need to be addressed as the situation continues to unfold.

Within mere days, opposition groups, predominantly led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), executed a series of coordinated attacks, leading to the capture of numerous towns and laying siege to critical government positions <citation>https://www.thedefensenews.com/news-details/The-Lightning-Offensive-A-Detailed-Timeline-of-Rebel-Forces-Multi-Front-Attack-on-Syria/</citation>.

Alongside these territorial advancements, the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) are experiencing heightened tensions with the Turkish-backed Syrian National Army (SNA). Clashes have escalated, particularly around areas of strategic importance such as the Tishrin Dam, further complicating the fractured landscape of control and influence in northern Syria <citation>https://www.newarab.com/news/syrias-tishrin-dam-sees-fierce-clashes-between-sna-and-sdf</citation>.

Moreover, the humanitarian situation is dire with approximately 178,000 individuals displaced due to the recent escalations in northwest Syria. IDPs face severe challenges in accessing basic needs including shelter and health care, as local administrations scramble to adapt to the influx of people seeking refuge from ongoing hostilities <citation>https://www.acaps.org/fileadmin/Data_Product/Main_media/20241206_ACAPS_Briefing_note_Syria_escalation_of_conflict_in_the_northwest.pdf</citation>.
